Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on a Facebook post that has been widely shared but does not provide any credible evidence or official sources to back up the claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that burglars are going door to door with contaminated face masks in a new scam, without providing any evidence or credible sources to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the Victoria Police, as well as authorities in other countries, have debunked the claim and stated that they are unaware of any instances of this nature occurring.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the threat by suggesting that burglars are specifically targeting individuals by going door to door with contaminated face masks, which may create unnecessary fear and panic.
Understate: There is no evidence to suggest that the claim is understating any information or downplaying the severity of the situation.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by relying on a Facebook post and circulating on social media without providing any credible sources or official statements to support the claim.
Exist alternative explanation: There is no alternative explanation provided in the claim.
